results_summary: Treatment with pine pollen polysaccharides (PPM60-III) and sulfated polysaccharides (SPPM60-III) improved body weight, reduced disease activity scores, lowered pro-inflammatory factors, increased anti-inflammatory factors, enhanced tight junction protein expression, and suppressed necroptosis-related proteins in mice with ulcerative colitis.
population_specificity: Mice with dextran sodium sulfate-induced ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-aging effects of pine pollen in human diploid fibroblast cells and a D-galactose-induced aging mouse model.
results_summary: Pine pollen delayed cellular senescence in 2BS cells by enhancing proliferation, reducing senescence markers, and reversing aging-related molecular changes. In mice, it improved neural activity, reduced inflammatory cytokines, and inhibited AGEs formation, similar to the effects of aminoguanidine.
population_specificity: Human diploid fibroblast 2BS cells and C57BL/6J mice.
effective_dosage: 1 mg/mL and 2 mg/mL (for cells); subcutaneous D-galactose injections (for mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of slash pine pollen supplementation on thrips reproductive parameters when added to an onion plant diet.
results_summary: The study found that slash pine pollen supplementation led to a trimodal distribution of oviposition, increased oviposition rates, higher female offspring production, and a four-fold increase in net reproduction of F. fusca on pollen-treated onions.
population_specificity: Frankliniella fusca (thrips) females on onion seedlings.
study_duration: Series of ten 2-day intervals (20 days total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Masson pine pollen aqueous extracts (MPPAE) could protect human hepatic cells (L-02) from oxidative damage induced by CCl4.
results_summary: MPPAE alleviated CCl4-induced cell morphology changes and inhibited abnormal rises in ALT and AST activities in a dose-dependent manner but did not prevent reduced cell proliferation. A high dose (400 mg/L) nearly restored normal nucleus appearance.
population_specificity: In vitro human hepatic cell line (L-02).
effective_dosage: Different concentrations, with 400 mg/L as the high dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties of pine pollen extract (PPE) and its effects on inflammatory mediators and enzymes.
results_summary: PPE demonstrated strong antioxidant activity, reduced oxidative stress markers, and inhibited pro-inflammatory mediators in macrophages. It also suppressed MMP production and JNK activation in synovial sarcoma cells.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using RAW 264.7 macrophages and SW982 human synovial sarcoma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanisms of diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) and identify protective targets of D-pinitol (DP) in an elderly diabetic mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that DP normalized 216 phosphorylation sites on 182 proteins in diabetic mice, affecting pathways like glucagon signaling, insulin signaling, mitophagy, apoptosis, and longevity regulation. Two consensus motifs targeted by Src and epidermal growth factor receptor were identified between treated and untreated groups.
population_specificity: Elderly diabetic mice (SAMP8 strain)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism of action of pinitol against endoplasmic reticulum stress-mediated hepatic ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI) and compare its effects with thymoquinone in rats.
results_summary: Pinitol (10 and 20 mg/kg) effectively protected against hepatic IRI by reducing oxidative stress, pro-inflammatory cytokines, and endoplasmic reticulum stress markers, while improving mitochondrial function and inhibiting apoptosis. TQ showed a more pronounced protective effect than pinitol.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pine pollen extract (PE) on arthritis symptoms and inflammatory markers in mouse models of Freund's complete adjuvant-induced arthritis and collagen-induced arthritis.
results_summary: Pine pollen extract significantly reduced hindpaw swelling, inflammatory cytokines (TNF-alpha, IL-1beta, IL-6), and improved cholesterol profiles in arthritis-induced mice. It also lowered rheumatoid factor, oxidative stress markers, and LDL-cholesterol levels in collagen-induced arthritis models.
population_specificity: DBA/1J mice with induced arthritis (Freund's complete adjuvant and collagen-induced models).
effective_dosage: 100 and 200 mg/kg per day, orally administered.
study_duration: 21 days for FCA-induced arthritis, 49 days for collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between pine nut ingestion and the development of cacogeusia ("pine mouth"), including symptom onset, duration, and potential causes.
results_summary: The study found that pine nut ingestion was associated with cacogeusia, typically appearing 1-3 days after consumption and lasting up to 2 weeks, with symptoms resolving without treatment. Online reports and search trends during early 2009 suggested a rise in such cases, though no specific cause or mechanism was identified.
population_specificity: A 36-year-old male case study, supplemented by online reports from unspecified individuals.
study_duration: Symptoms monitored over 5 days (case study); online reports noted durations up to 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and potential mechanisms of d-pinitol against DSS-induced colitis in mice.
results_summary: d-Pinitol significantly alleviated colitis symptoms, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and activated the Nrf2/ARE pathway while improving PPAR-γ levels, showing superior efficacy to SASP.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiproliferative and apoptotic effects of D-pinitol on human leukemia MOLT-4 cells.
results_summary: D-pinitol induced cytotoxicity, ROS generation, and apoptosis in MOLT-4 cells in a dosage-dependent manner, while modulating apoptotic protein expression (elevating Bax, Caspase-3, Caspase-9, and attenuating Bcl-2).
population_specificity: Human leukemia MOLT-4 cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for determining D-pinitol levels in rat plasma and study its pharmacokinetics to assess its potential as a therapeutic agent for type II diabetes.
results_summary: The study developed a validated method for measuring D-pinitol in rat plasma, showing slow elimination and high affinity for blood protein binding. Pharmacokinetic parameters like Cmax (77.8 ± 19.5 ng/mL) and AUC (1265.5 ± 479.3 µg/L*h) were reported after intragastric administration.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pinitol, alone or in combination with curcumin, could protect PC12 cells against arsenic-induced toxicity.
results_summary: Pretreatment with Pinitol, both alone and in combination with curcumin, rescued PC12 cells from arsenic-induced toxicity by modulating pro-survival and cell death-related proteins. The combined treatment showed stronger protective effects than individual treatments.
population_specificity: PC12 cells (a rat neuronal cell line)
effective_dosage: 1, 2.5, 5, and 10 μM (final selected dose for combination: 5 μM)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of D-pinitol on imiquimod-induced psoriasis-like skin inflammation in mice, focusing on the NF-κB pathway genes.
results_summary: D-pinitol reduced skin abrasion, epithelial thickness, inflammation, and collagen-occupied regions in psoriasis-like mice. It also improved lipid profiles, antioxidant enzyme levels, and modulated inflammatory and NF-κB pathway genes.
population_specificity: IMQ-induced psoriasis-like mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pinitol could inhibit microglia-associated neuroinflammation induced by LPS in BV2 microglia.
results_summary: Pinitol reduced LPS-induced oxidative stress, suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6), and inhibited NO and PGE2 production by blocking iNOS and COX-2 expression. It also prevented NF-κB activation and increased TREM2 expression, which mediated its anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: BV2 microglia (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of pinitol on renal function in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: Pinitol reduced urinary albumin/creatinine ratio by 50%, prevented glomerular expansion, restored pressure-natriuresis, and ameliorated renal lesions and marker expression in diabetic rats.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats (euglycemic, 8-week, and 16-week diabetic groups).
study_duration: Treatment duration varied by group (8-week and 16-week diabetic rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms behind D-pinitol's vascular effects in mouse mesenteric arteries and its potential hypotensive effects.
results_summary: D-pinitol induced endothelium- and NO-dependent vasodilation in mouse mesenteric arteries, increased nitrite concentration, and reduced systolic blood pressure in normotensive mice. The effect was mediated through eNOS activation by the calcium-calmodulin complex.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-pinitol could protect against cyclosporine A (CsA)-induced renal injury by reducing oxidative stress and enhancing antioxidant pathways.
results_summary: D-pinitol significantly reduced CsA-induced renal damage by lowering serum creatinine, improving urine osmolality, and reducing fibrosis and inflammation. It activated antioxidant pathways (Sirt1 and Nrf2) and increased levels of antioxidant enzymes.
population_specificity: Male ICR mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diuretic and neuropharmacological effects of d-pinitol, including its potential mechanisms of action in anxiety, depression, and convulsions.
results_summary: d-pinitol showed no diuretic effects but demonstrated significant anxiolytic-like (ED50 = 70 mg/kg) and antidepressant-like (ED50 = 26 mg/kg) activity, as well as anticonvulsant effects (100 mg/kg). These effects were linked to GABAergic (anxiolytic/anticonvulsant) and noradrenergic (antidepressant) systems.
population_specificity: Mice
interactions: Flumazenil (2 mg/kg) reversed anxiolytic/anticonvulsant effects; yohimbine (1 mg/kg) and prazosin (0.05 mg/kg) abolished antidepressant effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of D-Pinitol against carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced liver toxicity in rats.
results_summary: D-Pinitol significantly reduced serum marker enzymes and lipid peroxidation levels while increasing antioxidant levels, demonstrating protective effects against CCl4-induced hepatotoxicity. CYP expression was also investigated, suggesting D-Pinitol may reduce metabolic activation of xenobiotics through its antioxidant properties.
population_specificity: Rats (six groups, six animals each)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of pinitol in obese individuals, focusing on its impact on ER stress, SIRT1, and inflammatory markers in PBMCs, VAT, and SAT.
results_summary: Pinitol consumption reduced IL6 and TNFα levels in circulation and increased SIRT1 expression in PBMCs. Ex vivo experiments showed reduced inflammatory markers and ER stress in SAT but not VAT, with upregulation of SIRT1 and insulin-signaling pathways in SAT.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (13 in the intervention study, 34 in the ex vivo study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pinitol-enriched beverage used in intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and characterize monophosphinite ligands derived from Pinitol and evaluate their catalytic performance in asymmetric hydrogenation reactions.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized several ruthenium and osmium complexes using Pinitol-derived ligands, which demonstrated catalytic activity in asymmetric hydrogenation reactions, yielding high conversions but low enantiomeric excesses.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro chemical synthesis and catalysis study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism of D-pinitol in treating type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and its effects on insulin-mediated glucose uptake in diabetic rats.
results_summary: D-pinitol reduced fasting blood glucose by 12.63% in the high-dosage group, improved glucose tolerance, and enhanced glycogen synthesis by modulating the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway. It also promoted the expression of key proteins involved in insulin signaling and glycogen regulation.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats with induced type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) via high-fat diet and streptozocin injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether D-pinitol could inhibit tumor growth in DMBA-induced rat mammary carcinogenesis and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: D-pinitol significantly reduced tumor volume, decreased NF-κB activation, modulated p53 and caspase-3 proteins, reduced Bcl-2 expression, and lowered inflammatory cytokines and tumor markers, leading to apoptosis and suppression of breast cancer.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with DMBA-induced mammary tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-metastasis effects of D-pinitol in human prostate cancer cells.
results_summary: D-pinitol reduced migration and invasion of prostate cancer cells (PC3 and DU145) at noncytotoxic concentrations by decreasing αvβ3 integrin expression, FAK phosphorylation, c-Src kinase activity, and NF-kB activation.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer cells (PC3 and DU145).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Pinitol and D-chiro-inositol could extend longevity and improve health span in Drosophila, while investigating potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Pinitol extended adult longevity in Drosophila, improved resistance to oxidative and starvation stress, enhanced health span without reducing fecundity, and activated dFOXO via S6K and JNK signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Drosophila (fruit flies), both male and female.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of soy pinitol on adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 preadipocytes and its potential role as an insulin sensitizer.
results_summary: Pinitol did not inhibit lipid accumulation or affect certain adipogenesis-related factors but increased expression of adiponectin, GLUT4, IRS, C/EBPalpha, and PPARgamma mRNAs at 0.5 mM and 1 mM doses. It showed no toxicity or dose-dependent effects on cell growth inhibition.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 preadipocyte cell line

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of soy pinitol on factors involved in foam cell formation, particularly its impact on lipid accumulation, cytokine secretion, and macrophage scavenger receptor expression.
results_summary: Pinitol slightly inhibited foam cell formation in a dose-dependent manner, significantly reduced the release of certain cytokines (TNF-alpha, MCP-1, IL-1beta, IL-8), and down-regulated gene expressions of CD36, CD68, and MMP-9 compared to controls.
population_specificity: Differentiated THP-1 macrophages

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pinitol therapy on glucose metabolism, lipid profiles, and adipocytokine levels in poorly controlled type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: Pinitol treatment significantly reduced fasting glucose, post-prandial glucose, and hemoglobin A1c levels but did not affect lipid profiles or adipocytokine levels. Serum c-peptide levels were higher in the unresponsive group compared to the responsive group.
population_specificity: Twenty type 2 diabetic patients poorly controlled with hypoglycemic drugs (sulfonylurea, metformin, and/or insulin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether d-pinitol regulates dendritic cell (DC) functions, including surface molecule expression, cytokine production, endocytosis, and signaling pathways, and its influence on Th1/Th2 immune responses in vivo.
results_summary: d-pinitol significantly inhibited CD80, CD86, MHC class I/II expression, IL-12, and IFN-gamma production in LPS-stimulated DC, enhanced mannose receptor-mediated endocytosis, and impaired Th1 responses while maintaining normal cell-mediated immunity. It also inhibited LPS-induced MAPKs and NF-kappaB activation.
population_specificity: Murine bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (DC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the leaching rates of pinitol and carbohydrates from soybeans during imbibition and the effect of hypochlorite treatment on these rates.
results_summary: Pinitol leached much faster than carbohydrates initially, with a pinitol/carbohydrate ratio of 3.4 in the first 20 minutes, declining to 0.29 for fully imbibed seeds. Hypochlorite treatment significantly increased carbohydrate leaching but had little effect on pinitol.
population_specificity: Soybeans (Glycine max var Sparks)
study_duration: Initial 20 minutes of imbibition, followed by full imbibition

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the blood glucose-lowering effects of pinitol (positive control) against different doses of SBE in hyperglycemic subjects.
results_summary: Pinitol was used as a positive control, but the abstract does not report its specific efficacy results compared to baseline or other groups. The study focused more on SBE's effects, which significantly reduced blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: Hyperglycemic subjects with fasting blood glucose levels of 100-150 mg/dL

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer activity and mechanisms of a piperine derivative (1f) against MCF-7 breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The piperine derivative (1f) inhibited MCF-7 cell growth in a dose-dependent manner, induced apoptosis, increased ROS levels, and modulated gene expression linked to DNA repair, ER-α, and PI3K/AKT signaling pathways.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and urate-lowering effects of novel piperine derivatives, particularly compound 39, as a potential therapy for gout.
results_summary: Compound 39 demonstrated significant analgesic and urate-lowering effects, high stability, good oral bioavailability (34%), and a favorable safety profile with no acute toxicity observed in liver microsomes, cells, or animals. It also reversed tissue damage and inflammation in hyperuricemic mice.
population_specificity: Hyperuricemia model mice (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral administration of soybean-derived pinitol improves insulin sensitivity in obese subjects with diet-treated type 2 diabetes or glucose intolerance.
results_summary: The study found that pinitol treatment significantly increased plasma levels of pinitol and D-chiro-inositol but did not improve insulin sensitivity, glucose production, or free fatty acid and glycerol metabolism. No toxicity was observed during the study.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (BMI = 36.6 kg/m²) with diet-treated type 2 diabetes or glucose intolerance (HbA1c = 6.8%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cocrystallization of curcumin with piperine (CUR-PIP CoCry) could enhance bioavailability and therapeutic efficacy in treating urinary bladder cancer.
results_summary: The CUR-PIP CoCry significantly improved drug release, permeability, and pharmacokinetic parameters (5.7-fold increase in Cmax and 7.9-fold increase in AUC0-12 hr) compared to curcumin alone. It also suppressed IGF2 overexpression and enhanced anticancer efficacy in a bladder cancer rat model.
population_specificity: N-Methyl Nitrosourea-induced bladder cancer rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-cancer properties of piperine, focusing on its mechanisms of action and potential therapeutic applications in oncology.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrated anti-cancer effects by targeting multiple signaling pathways (PI3K/Akt/mTOR, ERK1/2, Wnt/β-catenin, NF-kB/AP-1), inducing cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, and reducing inflammation. Nanoformulations improved its bioavailability and efficacy, with synergistic effects observed when combined with other therapies.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies referenced, but no human population details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of a novel Piperine derivative, YL-1-9, against breast cancer by assessing its effects on cell proliferation, adhesion, invasion, migration, and apoptosis.
results_summary: YL-1-9 significantly inhibited breast cancer cell proliferation, adhesion, invasion, and migration while inducing cell cycle arrest and promoting apoptosis. It downregulated key proteins in the CDK4/6-cyclin D-Rb-E2F and Caspase 3/Bax/Bcl-2 pathways, suggesting strong anticancer activity.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (in vitro) and chick embryo chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) model (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the precise binding interactions of piperine with PPARγ-LBD and assess its potential as a modulator of PPARγ function.
results_summary: The study found that piperine binds to PPARγ-LBD via hydrogen-bonding and hydrophobic interactions, acting as a partial agonist or antagonist under certain conditions, with weaker agonistic activity compared to full agonists. These findings suggest piperine's potential as a therapeutic candidate for metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the regulatory effects of piperine (PIP) on glucose homeostasis and its potential as a treatment for metabolic disorders associated with disrupted glucose balance.
results_summary: The study highlights PIP's promising role in modulating glucose metabolism through various biochemical pathways, with evidence from cell models, animal studies, and human clinical trials supporting its efficacy in improving glucose homeostasis and metabolic function.
population_specificity: Cell models, animal studies, and human clinical trials (specific human population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine could enhance the antimicrobial activity of clarithromycin against fast-growing non-tuberculous mycobacteria, both extracellularly and intracellularly.
results_summary: Piperine modulated clarithromycin's activity, reducing the minimum inhibitory concentration by up to 16 times extracellularly, including against resistant isolates, and prolonged its bacteriostatic effect for 96 hours. The combination also showed modest improvement in intramacrophage environments, possibly by facilitating clarithromycin entry into macrophages.
population_specificity: Clinical isolates of fast-growing non-tuberculous mycobacteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate piperine's potential as an mTOR inhibitor and its effects on HCT-116 colon cancer cell viability and migration.
results_summary: Piperine showed strong binding affinity to mTOR, comparable to rapamycin, and significantly reduced cancer cell viability and migration in vitro. Molecular dynamics simulations confirmed stable binding, suggesting potential as a cancer therapy candidate.
population_specificity: HCT-116 colon cancer cell line
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 84.5 µM (24h), 46.3 µM (48h), and 19.73 µM (72h)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine (PIP) could effectively inhibit DHODH and synergize with DHA to induce ferroptosis for anticancer therapy.
results_summary: PIP functioned as a potent DHODH inhibitor, preventing detoxification of lipid hydroperoxides and enhancing lipid peroxidation when combined with DHA, leading to effective anticancer effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effect of a 308-nm excimer laser and piperine on vitiligo treatment and the molecular mechanism involving melanin synthesis regulation via keratinocyte paracrine activity.
results_summary: The combined treatment promoted melanin synthesis-related cytokine secretion, inhibited proinflammatory cytokines, activated the PTEN/PDK1/GSK3b pathway, and enhanced melanocyte proliferation and migration while reducing apoptosis. The combination was more effective than either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Cells (keratinocytes and melanocytes) and animal models of vitiligo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining piperine with prednisolone could improve clinical symptoms and immune responses in rats with rheumatoid arthritis compared to using either compound alone.
results_summary: The combination of piperine and prednisolone at half doses led to greater reductions in disease severity, weight improvement, and histopathological changes than full doses of either drug alone. The combined treatment also showed favorable biochemical test results and decreased expression of certain immune-related genes.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with rheumatoid arthritis induced by Freund's complete adjuvant.
effective_dosage: Piperine (100 mg kg-1 orally), prednisolone (10.00 mg kg-1 orally), or half doses of each in combination.
study_duration: Treatment started on day five post-induction and continued until day 23 post-induction (18 days total).
interactions: Positive interaction noted with prednisolone, enhancing therapeutic effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining piperine (PIP) with tamoxifen (TMF) in liposomal formulations could enhance the anticancer efficacy of TMF against breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that PIP and TMF, when loaded into liposomes (especially PEGylated ones), showed improved cytotoxicity (lower IC50 values) and enhanced cellular uptake in MCF-7 breast cancer cells compared to their pure forms.
population_specificity: MCF-7 human breast carcinoma cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: PIP (90.3 ± 10.2 μg/mL), TMF (40.9 ± 5.9 μg/mL), TMF-PIP-LPs (21 ± 1.6 μg/mL), TMF-PIP-PEG-LPs (10 ± 0.5 μg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial, antibiofilm, and photocatalytic properties of piperine-driven nano-zinc oxide (ZnONPs) against multi-drug resistant non-typhoidal Salmonella (NTS) and assess its potential for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that piperine-driven ZnONPs exhibited strong antibacterial and antibiofilm activity against MDR-NTS, demonstrated photocatalytic dye degradation under various light sources, and showed minimal toxicity in safety assays.
population_specificity: Multi-drug resistant non-typhoidal Salmonella (NTS) strains and in vitro models (HEK cell lines, chicken RBCs).
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentration (62.50 µg/mL) and minimum bactericidal concentration (125 µg/mL) of ZnONPs.
study_duration: Time-kill kinetic assay (6 hours), biofilm inhibition (24 and 48 hours), photocatalytic studies (4 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the antifungal ability of piperine (PIP) and assess its therapeutic potential in treating Aspergillus fumigatus keratitis.
results_summary: PIP effectively inhibited A. fumigatus growth, reduced fungal load and inflammatory cell aggregation, and alleviated pyroptosis by inhibiting the mTOR/HIF-1α signaling pathway. It also showed synergistic effects when combined with NATA.
population_specificity: Human corneal epithelial cells (HCECs), RAW264.7 cells, and mice fungal keratitis models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine, when combined with curcumin, improves body composition, phase angle, and functional capacity in patients with mild to moderate inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: The curcumin plus piperine group showed significant reductions in muscle depletion, with improvements in fat-free mass and phase angle compared to placebo, suggesting enhanced body composition in IBD patients.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18+ with mild to moderate IBD and intact kidney/liver function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Piperine (PPN) could inhibit melanin biosynthesis and serve as a potential skin whitening agent or treatment for hyperpigmentation.
results_summary: Piperine treatment reduced melanin production in a dose-dependent manner, decreased tyrosinase activity, and downregulated key melanogenesis-related genes. It also increased ERK phosphorylation, leading to MITF degradation and reduced melanin content, effects that were reversible with ERK or proteasomal inhibitors.
population_specificity: Melan-A cells (a murine melanocyte cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer effects of a novel piperine derivative, MHJ-LN, against triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) through in vitro and in vivo experiments.
results_summary: MHJ-LN demonstrated significant antitumor activity in TNBC by activating the MDM2-p53 pathway, inducing apoptosis, and blocking G1/S cell cycle progression. The compound effectively inhibited TNBC cell proliferation, adhesion, migration, and invasion.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells and xenograft models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of piperine in enhancing curcumin delivery via an in situ forming gel for treating inflammatory and degenerative joint diseases.
results_summary: Piperine doubled the curcumin release compared to curcumin alone in the gel, demonstrating a synergistic effect. The formulation showed sustained drug release over 96 hours, with release governed by diffusion and lipid structure swelling/erosion.
population_specificity: Human skin explants (ex vivo) were used; no specific human population was studied in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the formulation of curcumin and piperine (CP) in nanoparticles and dissolving microneedles to enhance solubility, bioavailability, and antimalarial efficacy.
results_summary: The NPs-CP-DMN formulation demonstrated good mechanical strength, rapid dissolution (10 min), effective permeation, and significant antiplasmodial activity (IC50 of 35.9 μg/mL) against P. falciparum FCR3 strain, with no toxicity (hemolysis <5%).
population_specificity: In vitro and ex vivo models (no human subjects specified).
effective_dosage: NPs-CP concentrations (35:40:50 w/w) with PVA and PVP polymers (35:65, 40:60, 50:50 ratios).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanisms and therapeutic effects of piperine (PIP) in treating silicosis using bioinformatics, network pharmacology, and experimental validation.
results_summary: PIP significantly reduced inflammation and fibrosis in a murine silicosis model, inhibited cytokine expression, ROS generation, macrophage apoptosis, and modulated the JAK2-STAT3 pathway. The study validated PIP as a promising candidate for silicosis treatment.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice) and in vitro studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop piperine-loaded solid lipid microparticles (SLMs) and evaluate their anti-arthritic potential in comparison to diclofenac sodium.
results_summary: The study found that piperine-loaded SLMs exhibited sustained release (87.82% to 94.92% over 24 hours) and significantly reduced arthritis severity in rats, comparable to diclofenac sodium. The formulations followed zero-order and Korsmeyer-Peppas release kinetics.
population_specificity: Rats with induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining curcumin:piperine with sorafenib enhances the suppression of breast cancer cell survival by modulating microRNAs and signaling pathways.
results_summary: The combination of sorafenib and curcumin:piperine suppressed MCF-7 cell survival, downregulated oncomirs and cancer-promoting genes, upregulated tumor suppressor miRNAs and E-cadherin, and induced apoptosis and cell cycle arrest.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of piperine, atorvastatin, and fenofibrate on the male reproductive system in rats.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrated reproductive toxicity when administered alone, but fenofibrate showed protective effects against piperine-induced toxicity when co-administered.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
interactions: Fenofibrate showed protective effects against piperine-induced reproductive toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether piperine could enhance the bioavailability, potency, and reduce the toxicity of Ezetimibe (EZ) while improving its antihyperlipidemic effects.
results_summary: Piperine combined with EZ significantly reduced LDL, TC, TG, and VLDL levels while increasing HDL levels in hyperlipidemic rats. Liver histology showed normalization of hepatocytes and periportal areas in treated rats, and EZ's plasma concentration peaked within 4 hours and remained detectable for 24 hours.
population_specificity: Rats with propylthiouracil-induced and triton X-100-induced hyperlipidemia.
effective_dosage: Piperine at 5-20 mg/kg body weight; EZ at 10 mg/kg body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro protoscolicidal activity of piperine-loaded mesoporous silica nanoparticles (PIP-MSNs) against Echinococcus granulosus protoscoleces.
results_summary: PIP-MSNs demonstrated strong protoscolicidal activity, killing 89.67% and 94.67% of protoscoleces at 375 and 500 µg/mL concentrations, respectively, after 180 minutes. The nanoparticles showed high drug loading efficiency (60%) and sustained release (75% after 24 hours), with no significant cytotoxicity (cell viability > 90%).
population_specificity: In vitro study on Echinococcus granulosus protoscoleces.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which piperine influences cancer-associated pain induced by microglia activation.
results_summary: Piperine effectively relieved cancer-associated pain in mice by upregulating miR-150-5p, inhibiting CXCL12 expression, and reducing microglia levels at the lesion site. It also inhibited microglia-induced cancer-associated pain.
population_specificity: Mice with tumor cell implantation (TCI) as a model for cancer-associated pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of curcumin-piperine supplementation on oxidative stress, laboratory factors, and macular vascular health in patients with diabetic retinopathy.
results_summary: Curcumin-piperine significantly improved oxidative stress markers (total antioxidant capacity, superoxide dismutase) and reduced malondialdehyde and creatinine levels, but had no significant effect on CRP, FBG, TG, BUN, OCT, or OCTA. No adverse reactions were reported.
population_specificity: 60 patients with diabetic retinopathy, aged 30-65 years.
effective_dosage: 1010 mg/day (two tablets per day, each containing 500 mg curcuminoids and 5 mg piperine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether niosomal nanoparticles encapsulating curcumin and piperine could mitigate paraquat-induced acute pulmonary toxicity in mice.
results_summary: The study found that piperine, combined with curcumin in niosomal nanoparticles, effectively reversed oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction caused by paraquat exposure, demonstrating potent antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prophylactic effects of piperine in preventing liver injury induced by paracetamol overdose in mice.
results_summary: Piperine maintained ALT levels and oxidative damage biomarkers similar to controls, reduced hepatocyte necrosis and TNF-α levels, and modulated CYP2E1 and inflammasome pathway gene expression. Higher doses (P40) also normalized hepatic hyperemia and MMP-9 activity.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with acute liver injury induced by paracetamol overdose.
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg (P20) and 40 mg/kg (P40) administered for eight consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop zein-based nanocarriers for piperine delivery and evaluate the impact of surfactants on stability and in vitro drug release characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that surfactant-stabilized zein nanoparticles enhanced piperine solubility in the gastrointestinal tract and provided sustained release, with Tween 80-stabilized nanoparticles showing superior performance. The formulations demonstrated thermal stability, resistance to aggregation, and good redispersibility after lyophilization.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of piperine on cell viability, cellular stresses, apoptosis, its relationship with the JNK signaling pathway, and its interaction with sorafenib in hepatocellular carcinoma.
results_summary: Piperine significantly increased cellular stresses, apoptosis, and activated JNK signaling in hepatocellular carcinoma cells, with additive or synergistic effects when combined with sorafenib. JNK inhibition reduced piperine-induced effects.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2 and Hep3B) and non-cancerous hepatocyte (AML12) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of piperine on orlistat-induced liver toxicity in obese male rats.
results_summary: Piperine combined with orlistat enhanced weight loss, improved biochemical markers (lipid profile, liver enzymes), reduced hepatic steatosis and duodenal inflammation, and upregulated genes related to fatty acid oxidation, carbohydrate metabolism, detoxification, and oxidative stress response.
population_specificity: Obese male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize Piperine's potential as an anticancer agent, including its sources, mechanisms, preclinical studies, and clinical trial prospects.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrates dual roles in directly inhibiting tumor growth and enhancing the bioavailability of chemotherapeutic drugs, with low toxicity and efficacy across multiple cancer cell lines and animal models. However, no clinical trial data for cancer patients exists yet.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies involved various cancer cell lines (e.g., breast, prostate, lung) and animal models (e.g., mice, rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate piperine's potential as a chemopreventive agent and its dual role in radiosensitization and radioprotection for cancer treatment.
results_summary: Piperine modulates key signaling pathways, inhibits cancer cell migration and invasion, enhances sensitivity to ionizing radiation, and protects healthy tissues by inhibiting NF-κB activation, reducing autophagy, and promoting apoptosis in cancer cells.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cancer treatment context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cytotoxic and apoptotic effects of piperine, both alone and in combination with cisplatin, on oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) cells.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrated cytotoxic and apoptotic effects in a concentration-dependent manner. When combined with cisplatin, it showed a synergistic effect, leading to more pronounced inhibition of cell viability and stronger induction of apoptosis via increased Bax protein and reactive oxygen species (ROS) activity.
population_specificity: In-vitro cultured OSCC cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of piperine (PPN) using in vivo and in silico methods, focusing on its interaction with celecoxib (CXB) and ketoprofen (KPN).
results_summary: PPN significantly reduced licking frequency and paw edema in a dose-dependent manner but diminished the effects of CXB and KPN in combination therapy. It showed high affinity for COX-2, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects via COX-2 inhibition.
population_specificity: Young chicks with induced inflammation in the right hind paw.
interactions: Antagonistic interaction with celecoxib (CXB) and ketoprofen (KPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic effects of Piperine (PIP) and its albumin nanoparticle formulation (PIP-BSA NPs) in treating Adjuvant-induced arthritis (AIA) in rats.
results_summary: Both PIP and PIP-BSA NPs significantly reduced clinical scores and joint inflammation in AIA rats. PIP was superior for alleviating fibrin deposition and periosteal reactions, while PIP-BSA NPs were more effective in reducing bone inflammation and erosion. Both treatments suppressed serum levels of IL-17.
population_specificity: Adjuvant-induced arthritis (AIA) rats
effective_dosage: 40 mg PIP or 131 mg PIP-BSA NPs every two days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a PBPK model for piperine and predict potential food-drug interactions with CYP3A4 substrate drugs.
results_summary: The study successfully developed and validated a PBPK model for piperine, predicting significant increases in AUC for six CYP3A4 substrate drugs (ritonavir, nifedipine, cyclosporine, triazolam, alfentanil, and simvastatin) when co-administered with piperine. These findings suggest piperine may alter the pharmacokinetics of these drugs.
population_specificity: Humans
interactions: Significant interactions with CYP3A4 substrate drugs (ritonavir, nifedipine, cyclosporine, triazolam, alfentanil, and simvastatin)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro effect of piperine against T. gondii tachyzoites in infected Vero cell cultures.
results_summary: Piperine reduced T. gondii multiplication by 55.56% to 88.89% in a dose-dependent manner, showing stronger antiparasitic effects than harmaline. Cells treated with piperine exhibited lower parasitic proliferation compared to controls.
population_specificity: In vitro Vero cell cultures infected with T. gondii tachyzoites.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polymer-phospholipid dispersions could improve the solubility and bioaccessibility of piperine and curcumin.
results_summary: The study found that polymer-phospholipid dispersions enhanced the solubility and permeability of piperine, maintaining supersaturation and improving its bioaccessibility compared to its crystalline form.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel piperine-derived mitofusin activator (8015-P2) in reversing mitochondrial dysfunction and neurodegeneration in a mouse model of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 2A (CMT2A).
results_summary: The piperine derivative 8015-P2 demonstrated subnanomolar potency, improved mitochondrial fusion and motility, and reversed neuromuscular and sensory dysfunction in Mfn2 T105M knock-in mice. It also corrected histological and ultrastructural neurodegeneration and neurogenic myoatrophy.
population_specificity: Mfn2 T105M knock-in mice and human CMT2A patient-derived fibroblasts and reprogrammed motor neurons.
effective_dosage: Daily oral treatment (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of piperine on experimental autoimmune uveitis (EAU) in rats, focusing on clinical symptoms, immune responses, and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Piperine at 80 mg/kg demonstrated superior regression of clinical symptoms, increased nitric oxide levels, enhanced IDO activity, and favorable mRNA expression of IL-10 and TGF-β compared to lower doses. It also significantly reduced mRNA ratios of key inflammatory markers in EAU rats.
population_specificity: Lewis rats with induced experimental autoimmune uveitis (EAU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate piperine's potential to counteract chemoresistance in cancer cells and enhance the efficacy of chemotherapeutic agents.
results_summary: Piperine demonstrated antineoplastic properties by regulating key cellular signaling pathways and modulating drug resistance mechanisms, such as inhibiting P-glycoprotein (P-gp) and multidrug resistance-associated protein 1 (MRP-1). It also enhanced drug bioavailability and chemosensitization across various cancer types.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or preclinical models, not specified for human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a curcumin-piperine combination could improve cardiometabolic indices in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and hypertriglyceridemia.
results_summary: The study found that the curcumin-piperine combination significantly reduced triglycerides and fasting blood glucose levels, marginally reduced CRP levels, and improved energy/fatigue compared to placebo. No significant changes were observed in other parameters like anthropometric indices, lipid profile, insulin resistance, blood pressure, or mood.
population_specificity: 72 patients with T2DM and hypertriglyceridemia.
effective_dosage: 5 mg piperine combined with 500 mg curcuminoids, administered as a tablet.
